Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1023(2)(a): Each vote entitled to be cast may be voted for or against up to that number of candidates that is equal to the number of directors to be elected, or the shareholder may indicate abstention, but without cumulating the votes.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1023(2)(b): To be elected, a nominee shall receive a plurality of the votes cast by shareholders of shares entitled to vote in the election at a meeting at which a quorum is present.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1023(2)(c): (2)(b); 16-10a-810 Notwithstanding Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1023(2)(c)(ii): 16-10a-810 the day on which a person is selected by the board of directors to fill the office held by the director, which selection constitutes the filling of a vacancy by the board for the purpose of Section

Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1023(2)(e): The board of directors may select any qualified person to fill the office held by a director who receives more votes against than for election.

Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1023(3)(a): (2) Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1023(3)(b)(ii): (3)(b)(i) if there is no provision under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1023(4): (3) A person may not be considered a candidate for the purpose of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1023(5): A bylaw electing to be governed by this section may be repealed:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1023(5)(a): by the shareholders if originally adopted by the shareholders, unless otherwise provided by the bylaws; or
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1023(5)(b): by the board of directors or the shareholders, if originally adopted by the board of directors.


Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1101 Merger.
-----------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1101(1): 16-10a-1103 A domestic corporation may merge into another entity if:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1101(1)(a): 16-10a-1103 the board of directors of the domestic corporation adopts and its shareholders, if required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1101(1)(b): any other entity that plans to merge approves the plan of merger as provided by the statutes governing the entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1101(2): (1) The plan of merger referred to in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1101(2)(a): the name of each entity planning to merge and the name of the surviving entity into which each other entity plans to merge;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1101(2)(b): the terms and conditions of the merger;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1101(2)(c): the manner and basis of converting the ownership interests in each entity, in whole or part, into:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1101(2)(c)(i): ownership interests, obligations, or other securities of the surviving entity or another entity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1101(2)(c)(ii): cash or other property; and
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1101(2)(d): any amendments to the articles of incorporation or organization of the surviving entity to be effected by the merger.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1101(3): The plan of merger may set forth other provisions relating to the merger.


Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1102 Share exchange.
-------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1102(1): 16-10a-1103 A domestic corporation may acquire all of the outstanding shares of one or more classes or series of one or more domestic corporations if the board of directors of each corporation adopts a plan of share exchange and the shareholders of the corporation, if required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1102(2): (1) The plan of share exchange referred to in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1102(2)(a): the name of each corporation whose shares will be acquired and the name of the acquiring corporation;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1102(2)(b): the terms and conditions of the share exchange; and
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1102(2)(c): the manner and basis of exchanging the shares to be acquired for shares, obligations, or other securities of the acquiring or any other corporation or for money or other property in whole or part.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1102(3): The plan of share exchange may set forth other provisions relating to the share exchange.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1102(4): This section does not limit the power of a corporation to acquire all or part of the shares of one or more classes or series of another corporation through a voluntary exchange of shares or otherwise.


Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1103 Action on plan.
-------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1103(1): (7); 16-10a-1104 After adopting a plan of merger or share exchange, the board of directors of each corporation party to the merger, and the board of directors of each corporation whose shares will be acquired in the share exchange, shall submit the plan of merger to its shareholders for approval, except as provided in:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1103(1)(a): (7) Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1103(1)(b): 16-10a-1104 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1103(1)(c): the plan of share exchange.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1103(2): (5) For a plan of merger or share exchange to be approved:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1103(2)(a): the board of directors shall recommend the plan of merger or share exchange to the shareholders, unless the board of directors determines that because of conflict of interest or other special circumstances it should make no recommendation and communicates the basis for its determination to the shareholders with the plan; and
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1103(2)(b): (5) the shareholders entitled to vote on the plan of merger or share exchange shall approve the plan as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1103(3): The board of directors may condition its submission of the proposed merger or share exchange on any basis.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1103(4): 16-10a-705 The corporation shall give notice of the shareholders' meeting in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1103(5): (3) Unless this chapter, the articles of incorporation, the initial bylaws, the amended bylaws, or the board of directors acting pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1103(6): 16-10a-1004 Separate voting by voting groups is required on a plan of:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1103(6)(a): 16-10a-1004 merger if the plan contains a provision that, if contained in an amendment to the articles of incorporation, would require action by one or more separate voting groups on the amendment under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1103(6)(b): share exchange by each class or series of shares included in the share exchange, with each class or series constituting a separate voting group.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1103(7): 16-10a-1002 Action by the shareholders of the surviving corporation on a plan of merger is not required if:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1103(7)(a): 16-10a-1002 the articles of incorporation of the surviving corporation will not differ, except for amendments enumerated in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1103(7)(b): each shareholder of the surviving corporation whose shares were outstanding immediately before the merger will hold the same number of shares, with identical designations, preferences, limitations, and relative rights, immediately after the merger;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1103(7)(c): the number of voting shares outstanding immediately after the merger, plus the number of voting shares issuable as a result of the merger either by the conversion of securities issued pursuant to the merger or the exercise of rights and warrants issued pursuant to the merger, will not exceed by more than 20% the total number of voting shares of the surviving corporation outstanding immediately before the merger; and
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1103(7)(d): the number of participating shares outstanding immediately after the merger, plus the number of participating shares issuable as a result of the merger either by the conversion of securities issued pursuant to the merger or the exercise of rights and warrants issued pursuant to the merger, will not exceed by more than 20% the total number of participating shares outstanding immediately before the merger.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1103(8): (7) As used in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1103(8)(a): "Participating shares" means shares that entitle their holders to participate without limitation in distributions.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1103(8)(b): "Voting shares" means shares that entitle their holders to vote unconditionally in elections of directors.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1103(9): After a plan of merger or share exchange is approved, and at any time before the merger or share exchange becomes effective the merger or share exchange may be abandoned, subject to any contractual rights, without further shareholder action, in accordance with the procedure set forth in the plan of merger or share exchange or, if none is set forth, in the manner determined by the board of directors.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1103(10): 16-10a-1105 If a merger or share exchange is abandoned after articles of merger or share exchange have been filed by the division pursuant to Section


Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1104 Merger of parent and subsidiary.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1104(1): By complying with the provision of this section, a parent corporation owning at least 90% of the outstanding shares of each class of a subsidiary corporation may either merge the subsidiary into itself or merge itself into the subsidiary.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1104(2): (3) The board of directors of the parent shall adopt and its shareholders, if required by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1104(2)(a): the names of the parent and subsidiary and the name of the surviving entity;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1104(2)(b): the terms and conditions of the merger;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1104(2)(c): the manner and basis of converting the shares of each corporation into shares, obligations, or other securities of the surviving or any other corporation or into money or other property in whole or part;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1104(2)(d): any amendments to the articles of incorporation of the surviving corporation to be effected by the merger; and
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1104(2)(e): any other provisions relating to the merger as may be determined to be necessary or desirable.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1104(3): 16-10a-1103(1); (6); 16-10a-1103(7); 16-10a-1103(1); (6) A vote of the shareholders of the subsidiary is not required with respect to the merger. If the subsidiary will be the surviving corporation, the approval of the shareholders of the parent shall be sought in the manner provided in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1104(4): The parent shall mail a copy or summary of the plan of merger to each shareholder of the subsidiary (other than the parent) who does not waive this mailing requirement in writing.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1104(5): (4) The effective date of the merger may not be earlier than the date on which all shareholders of the subsidiary waived the mailing requirement of Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1105 Articles of merger or share exchange.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1105(1): 16-10a-1104; 16-10a-1104(5) After a plan of merger or share exchange is approved by the shareholders, or adopted by the board of directors if shareholder approval is not required, the surviving or acquiring corporation shall deliver to the division for filing articles of merger or share exchange setting forth:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1105(1)(a): the plan of merger or share exchange;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1105(1)(b): if shareholder approval was not required, a statement to that effect;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1105(1)(c): if approval of the shareholders of one or more corporations party to the merger or share exchange was required:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1105(1)(c)(i): the designation and number of outstanding shares, and number of votes entitled to be cast by each voting group entitled to vote separately on the plan as to each corporation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1105(1)(c)(ii): either the total number of votes cast for and against the plan by each voting group entitled to vote separately on the plan or the total number of undisputed votes cast for the plan separately by each voting group and a statement that the number of votes cast for the plan by each voting group entitled to vote separately was sufficient for approval by that voting group; and
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1105(1)(d): 16-10a-1104; 16-10a-1104(5) if the merger is being effected pursuant to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1105(1)(d)(i): a statement that immediately prior to the merger the parent owned at least 90% of the outstanding shares of each class of the subsidiary; and
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1105(1)(d)(ii): 16-10a-1104(5) the effective date of the merger and a statement that the effective date complies with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1105(2): A merger or share exchange takes effect upon the effective date of the articles of merger or share exchange, which may not be prior to the date of filing.


Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1106 Effect of merger or share exchange.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1106(1): Part 13, Dissenters' Rights When a merger takes effect:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1106(1)(a): Every other corporation party to the merger merges into the surviving corporation and the separate existence of every corporation except the surviving corporation ceases.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1106(1)(b): The title to all real estate and other property owned by each corporation party to the merger is transferred to and vested in the surviving corporation without reversion or impairment.  The transfer to and vesting in the surviving corporation occurs by operation of law.  No consent or approval of any other person is required in connection with the transfer or vesting unless consent or approval is specifically required in the event of merger by law or by express provision in any contract, agreement, decree, order, or other instrument to which any of the corporations so merged is a party or by which it is bound.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1106(1)(c): The surviving corporation has all liabilities of each corporation party to the merger.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1106(1)(d): A proceeding pending against any corporation party to the merger may be continued as if the merger did not occur, or the surviving corporation may be substituted in the proceeding for the corporation whose existence ceased.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1106(1)(e): The articles of incorporation of the surviving corporation are amended to the extent provided in the plan of merger.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1106(1)(f): Part 13, Dissenters' Rights The shares of each corporation party to the merger, which are to be converted into shares, obligations, or other securities of the surviving or any other corporation or into money or other property, are converted, and the former holders of the shares are entitled only to the rights provided in the articles of merger or to their rights under
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1106(2): Part 13, Dissenters' Rights When a share exchange takes effect, the shares of each acquired corporation are exchanged as provided in the plan, and the former holders of the shares are entitled only to the exchange rights provided in the articles of share exchange or to their rights under


Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1107 Merger or share exchange with foreign corporations.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1107(1): 16-10a-1105; 16-10a-1105; 16-10a-1101; 16-10a-1104; 16-10a-1105 A domestic corporation may merge with a foreign entity or enter into a share exchange with a foreign corporation if:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1107(1)(a): in a merger, the merger is permitted by the law of the state or country under whose law the foreign entity is incorporated or organized and the foreign entity complies with that law in effecting the merger;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1107(1)(b): in a share exchange, the corporation whose shares will be acquired is a domestic corporation, whether or not a share exchange is permitted by the law of the state or country under whose law the acquiring corporation is incorporated;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1107(1)(c): 16-10a-1105; 16-10a-1105 the foreign corporation complies with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1107(1)(d): 16-10a-1101; 16-10a-1104; 16-10a-1105 the domestic corporation complies with:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1107(1)(d)(i): 16-10a-1101; 16-10a-1104 the applicable provisions of Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1107(1)(d)(ii): 16-10a-1105 if it is the surviving corporation of the merger, Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1107(2): 16-17-301; Part 13, Dissenters' Rights; Part 15, Authority of Foreign Corporation to Transact Business Upon the merger or share exchange taking effect, the surviving foreign entity of a merger and the acquiring foreign corporation of a share exchange shall either:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1107(2)(a): 16-17-301 agree that service of process in a proceeding to enforce the rights of shareholders of each domestic corporation that is a party to the merger who exercise appraisal rights may be made in the manner provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1107(2)(b): Part 13, Dissenters' Rights promptly pay to the dissenting shareholders of each domestic corporation party to the merger or share exchange the amount, if any, to which they are entitled under
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1107(2)(c): Part 15, Authority of Foreign Corporation to Transact Business comply with
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1107(3): (2) Service effected pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1107(3)(a): the date the foreign entity receives the process, notice, or demand;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1107(3)(b): the date shown on the return receipt, if signed on behalf of the foreign entity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1107(3)(c): five days after mailing.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1107(4): (2) Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1107(5): This section does not limit the power of a foreign corporation to acquire all or part of the shares of one or more classes or series of a domestic corporation through a voluntary exchange of shares or otherwise.


Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1201 Sale or mortgage of property without shareholder approval.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1201(1): 16-10a-1202 A corporation may, on the terms and conditions and for the consideration determined by the board of directors:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1201(1)(a): 16-10a-1202 sell, lease, exchange, or otherwise dispose of all, or substantially all, of its property in the usual and regular course of business or in a transaction not requiring shareholder approval as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1201(1)(b): mortgage, pledge, dedicate to the repayment of indebtedness, whether with or without recourse, or otherwise encumber any or all of its property whether or not in the usual and regular course of business; or
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1201(1)(c): transfer any or all of its property to a corporation all the shares of which are owned by the corporation.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1201(2): (1) Unless otherwise provided in the articles of incorporation, approval by the shareholders of a transaction described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1202 Sale of property requiring shareholder approval.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1202(1): A corporation may sell, lease, exchange, or otherwise dispose of all, or substantially all, of its property, with or without the good will, otherwise than in the usual and regular course of business, on the terms and conditions and for the consideration determined by the board of directors, if the board of directors proposes and the shareholders approve the transaction.  A sale, lease, exchange, or other disposition of all, or substantially all, of the property of a corporation, with or without the good will, other than in the usual and regular course of business and other than pursuant to a court order, in connection with its dissolution is subject to the requirements of this section, but a sale, lease, exchange, or other disposition of all, or substantially all, of the property of a corporation, with or without the good will, that is pursuant to a court order is not subject to the requirements of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1202(2): If a corporation is entitled to vote or otherwise consent, other than in the usual and regular course of its business, with respect to the sale, lease, exchange, or other disposition of all, or substantially all, of the property, with or without the good will, of another entity which it controls, and if the shares or other interests held by the corporation in the other entity constitute all, or substantially all, of the property of the corporation, then the corporation shall consent to the transaction only if the board of directors proposes and the shareholders approve the consent.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1202(3): (1); (2); (5); (6) For a transaction described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1202(3)(a): the board of directors shall recommend the transaction or the consent to the shareholders unless the board of directors determines that because of conflict of interest or other special circumstances it should make no recommendation and communicates the basis for its determination to the shareholders with the submission of the proposed transaction; and
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1202(3)(b): (5); (6) the shareholders entitled to vote on the transaction or the consent shall approve the transaction or the consent as provided in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1202(4): The board of directors may condition the effectiveness of the transaction or the consent on any basis.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1202(5): 16-10a-705; (1); (2); (1); (2); (1); (2) The corporation shall give notice in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1202(5)(a): (1); (2) state that the purpose, or one of the purposes, of the meeting is to consider:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1202(5)(a)(i): (1) in the case of action pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1202(5)(a)(ii): (2) in the case of action pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1202(5)(b): (1); (2) contain or be accompanied by a description of the transaction, in the case of action pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1202(6): 16-10a-1021; (4); (1); (2) Unless this chapter, the articles of incorporation, the initial bylaws or the bylaws as amended pursuant to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1202(7): (1); (2) After a transaction described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1202(8): 16-10a-640 A transaction that constitutes a distribution is governed by Section


Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1301 Definitions.
----------------------------------------------
For purposes ofUtah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1301(1): "Beneficial shareholder" means the person who is a beneficial owner of shares held in a voting trust or by a nominee as the record shareholder.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1301(2): "Corporation" means the issuer of the shares held by a dissenter before the corporate action, or the surviving or acquiring corporation by merger or share exchange of that issuer.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1301(3): 16-10a-1302; 16-10a-1320; 16-10a-1328 "Dissenter" means a shareholder who is entitled to dissent from corporate action under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1301(4): "Fair value" with respect to a dissenter's shares, means the value of the shares immediately before the effectuation of the corporate action to which the dissenter objects, excluding any appreciation or depreciation in anticipation of the corporate action.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1301(5): 15-1-1 "Interest" means interest from the effective date of the corporate action until the date of payment, at the statutory rate set forth in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1301(6): 16-10a-723 "Record shareholder" means the person in whose name shares are registered in the records of a corporation or the beneficial owner of shares that are registered in the name of a nominee to the extent the beneficial owner is recognized by the corporation as the shareholder as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1301(7): "Shareholder" means the record shareholder or the beneficial shareholder.


Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1302 Right to dissent.
---------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1302(1): 16-10a-1103; 16-10a-1104; 16-10a-1202(1); 16-10a-1202(2) A shareholder, whether or not entitled to vote, is entitled to dissent from, and obtain payment of the fair value of shares held by him in the event of, any of the following corporate actions:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1302(1)(a): 16-10a-1103; 16-10a-1104 consummation of a plan of merger to which the corporation is a party if:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1302(1)(a)(i): 16-10a-1103 shareholder approval is required for the merger by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1302(1)(a)(ii): 16-10a-1104 the corporation is a subsidiary that is merged with its parent under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1302(1)(b): consummation of a plan of share exchange to which the corporation is a party as the corporation whose shares will be acquired;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1302(1)(c): 16-10a-1202(1) consummation of a sale, lease, exchange, or other disposition of all, or substantially all, of the property of the corporation for which a shareholder vote is required under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1302(1)(d): 16-10a-1202(2) consummation of a sale, lease, exchange, or other disposition of all, or substantially all, of the property of an entity controlled by the corporation if the shareholders of the corporation were entitled to vote upon the consent of the corporation to the disposition pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1302(2): A shareholder is entitled to dissent and obtain payment of the fair value of his shares in the event of any other corporate action to the extent the articles of incorporation, bylaws, or a resolution of the board of directors so provides.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1302(3): (4); (1); 16-10a-707; 16-10a-704 Notwithstanding the other provisions of this part, except to the extent otherwise provided in the articles of incorporation, bylaws, or a resolution of the board of directors, and subject to the limitations set forth in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1302(3)(a): 16-10a-707 the record date fixed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1302(3)(b): 16-10a-704 the record date fixed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1302(3)(c): the effective date of the corporate action if the corporate action is authorized other than by a vote of shareholders.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1302(4): (3); (4) The limitation set forth in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1302(4)(a): shares of the corporation surviving the consummation of the plan of merger or share exchange;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1302(4)(b): shares of a corporation which at the effective date of the plan of merger or share exchange either will be listed on a national securities exchange registered under the federal Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended, or on the National Market System of the National Association of Securities Dealers Automated Quotation System, or will be held of record by more than 2,000 shareholders;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1302(4)(c): cash in lieu of fractional shares; or
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1302(4)(d): (4) any combination of the shares described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1302(5): A shareholder entitled to dissent and obtain payment for his shares under this part may not challenge the corporate action creating the entitlement unless the action is unlawful or fraudulent with respect to him or to the corporation.


Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1303 Dissent by nominees and beneficial owners.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1303(1): A record shareholder may assert dissenters' rights as to fewer than all the shares registered in his name only if the shareholder dissents with respect to all shares beneficially owned by any one person and causes the corporation to receive written notice which states the dissent and the name and address of each person on whose behalf dissenters' rights are being asserted.  The rights of a partial dissenter under this subsection are determined as if the shares as to which the shareholder dissents and the other shares held of record by him were registered in the names of different shareholders.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1303(2): A beneficial shareholder may assert dissenters' rights as to shares held on his behalf only if:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1303(2)(a): the beneficial shareholder causes the corporation to receive the record shareholder's written consent to the dissent not later than the time the beneficial shareholder asserts dissenters' rights; and
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1303(2)(b): the beneficial shareholder dissents with respect to all shares of which he is the beneficial shareholder.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1303(3): 16-10a-1322 The corporation may require that, when a record shareholder dissents with respect to the shares held by any one or more beneficial shareholders, each beneficial shareholder shall certify to the corporation that both he and the record shareholders of all shares owned beneficially by him have asserted, or will timely assert, dissenters' rights as to all the shares unlimited on the ability to exercise dissenters' rights.  The certification requirement shall be stated in the dissenters' notice given pursuant to Section

Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1330(1)(b): If the corporation does not bring an action within the 60-day period, the corporation shall pay each dissenter whose demand remains unresolved the amount demanded.

Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1330(2)(b): All such dissenters who are named as parties shall be served with a copy of the complaint.

Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1331 Court costs and counsel fees.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1331(1): 16-10a-1330; 16-10a-1328 The court in an appraisal proceeding commenced under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1331(2): 16-10a-1320; 16-10a-1328 The court may also assess the fees and expenses of counsel and experts for the respective parties, in amounts the court finds equitable:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1331(2)(a): 16-10a-1320; 16-10a-1328 against the corporation and in favor of any or all dissenters if the court finds the corporation did not substantially comply with the requirements of Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1331(2)(b): against either the corporation or one or more dissenters, in favor of any other party, if the court finds that the party against whom the fees and expenses are assessed acted arbitrarily, vexatiously, or not in good faith with respect to the rights provided by this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1331(3): If the court finds that the services of counsel for any dissenter were of substantial benefit to other dissenters similarly situated, and that the fees for those services should not be assessed against the corporation, the court may award to those counsel reasonable fees to be paid out of the amounts awarded the dissenters who were benefited.


Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1401 Authorization of dissolution prior to issuance of shares.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If a corporation has not yet issued shares, a majority of its directors, or if no directors have been elected or if elected directors are no longer serving, a majority of its incorporators may authorize the dissolution of the corporation.

Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1402 Authorization of dissolution after issuance of shares.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1402(1): (2) After shares have been issued, dissolution of a corporation may be authorized in the manner provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1402(2): (5) For a proposal to dissolve the corporation to be authorized:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1402(2)(a): the board of directors must recommend dissolution to the shareholders unless the board of directors determines that because of a conflict of interest or other special circumstances it should make no recommendation and communicates the basis for its determination to the shareholders; and
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1402(2)(b): (5) the shareholders entitled to vote on the proposal must approve the proposal to dissolve as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1402(3): The board of directors may condition the effectiveness of the dissolution on any basis.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1402(4): 16-10a-705 The corporation shall give notice in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1402(5): 16-10a-1021; (3) The proposal to dissolve must be approved by each voting group entitled to vote separately on the proposal, by a majority of all the votes entitled to be cast on the proposal by that voting group, unless a greater vote is required by the articles of incorporation, the initial bylaws or the bylaws amended pursuant to Section


Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1403 Articles of dissolution.
----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1403(1): 16-10a-1409; 16-10a-1401; 16-10a-1402 At any time after dissolution is authorized, the corporation may dissolve by delivering to the division for filing articles of dissolution setting forth:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1403(1)(a): the name of the corporation;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1403(1)(b): 16-10a-1409 the address of the corporation's principal office or, if none is to be maintained, a statement that the corporation will not maintain a principal office, and, if different from the address of the principal office or if no principal office is to be maintained, the address to which service of process may be mailed pursuant to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1403(1)(c): the date dissolution was authorized;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1403(1)(d): 16-10a-1401 if dissolution was authorized by the directors or the incorporators pursuant to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1403(1)(e): 16-10a-1402 if dissolution was approved by the shareholders pursuant to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1403(1)(e)(i): the number of votes entitled to be cast on the proposal to dissolve by each voting group entitled to vote separately thereon; and
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1403(1)(e)(ii): either the total number of votes cast for and against dissolution by each voting group or the total number of undisputed votes cast for dissolution by each voting group and a statement that the number cast for dissolution was sufficient for approval; and
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1403(1)(f): any additional information the division determines is necessary or appropriate.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1403(2): A corporation is dissolved upon the effective date of its articles of dissolution.


Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1404 Revocation of dissolution.
------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1404(1): A corporation may revoke its dissolution within 120 days after the effective date of the dissolution.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1404(2): 16-10a-1402 Revocation of dissolution shall be authorized in the same manner as the dissolution was authorized unless, in the case of authorization pursuant to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1404(3): (2); 16-10a-1401; (2); (2); 16-10a-1403(1)(e) After the revocation of dissolution is authorized, the corporation may revoke the dissolution by delivering to the division for filing articles of revocation of dissolution, together with a copy of its articles of dissolution, that set forth:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1404(3)(a): the name of the corporation;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1404(3)(b): the effective date of the dissolution that was revoked;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1404(3)(c): the date that the revocation of dissolution was authorized;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1404(3)(d): (2); 16-10a-1401 if pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1404(3)(e): (2) if pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1404(3)(f): (2); 16-10a-1403(1)(e) if the revocation of dissolution was approved pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1404(4): 16-10a-123(1); 16-10a-123(2) Revocation of dissolution is effective as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1404(5): When the revocation of dissolution is effective, it relates back to and takes effect as of the effective date of the dissolution and the corporation may carry on its business as if dissolution had never occurred.


Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1405 Effect of dissolution.
--------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1405(1): A dissolved corporation continues its corporate existence but may not carry on any business except that appropriate to wind up and liquidate its business and affairs, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1405(1)(a): collecting its assets;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1405(1)(b): disposing of its properties that will not be distributed in kind to its shareholders;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1405(1)(c): discharging or making provision for discharging its liabilities;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1405(1)(d): distributing its remaining property among its shareholders according to their interests; and
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1405(1)(e): doing every other act necessary to wind up and liquidate its business and affairs.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1405(2): Part 8, Directors and Officers Dissolution of a corporation does not:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1405(2)(a): transfer title to the corporation's property;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1405(2)(b): prevent transfer of its shares or securities, although the authorization to dissolve may provide for closing the corporation's share transfer records;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1405(2)(c): Part 8, Directors and Officers subject its directors or officers to standards of conduct different from those prescribed in
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1405(2)(d): change:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1405(2)(d)(i): quorum or voting requirements for its board of directors or shareholders;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1405(2)(d)(ii): provisions for selection, resignation, or removal of its directors or officers or both; or
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1405(2)(d)(iii): provisions for amending its bylaws or its articles of incorporation;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1405(2)(e): prevent commencement of a proceeding by or against the corporation in its corporate name;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1405(2)(f): abate or suspend a proceeding pending by or against the corporation on the effective date of dissolution; or
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1405(2)(g): terminate the authority of the registered agent of the corporation.


Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1406 Disposition of known claims by notification.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1406(1): A dissolved corporation may dispose of the known claims against it by following the procedures described in this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1406(2): A dissolved corporation electing to dispose of known claims pursuant to this section may give written notice of the dissolution to known claimants at any time after the effective date of the dissolution.  The written notice shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1406(2)(a): describe the information that must be included in a claim;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1406(2)(b): provide an address to which written notice of any claim must be given to the corporation;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1406(2)(c): state the deadline, which may not be fewer than 120 days after the effective date of the notice, by which the dissolved corporation must receive the claim; and
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1406(2)(d): state that unless sooner barred by any other state statute limiting actions, the claim will be barred if not received by the deadline.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1406(3): (2) Unless sooner barred by any other statute limiting actions, a claim against the dissolved corporation is barred if:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1406(3)(a): (2) a claimant was given notice under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1406(3)(b): the dissolved corporation delivers to the claimant written notice of rejection of the claim within 90 days after receipt of the claim and the claimant whose claim was rejected by the dissolved corporation does not commence a proceeding to enforce the claim within 90 days after the effective date of the rejection notice.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1406(4): Claims which are not rejected by the dissolved corporation in writing within 90 days after receipt of the claim by the dissolved corporation shall be considered accepted.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1406(5): (2) The failure of the dissolved corporation to give notice to any known claimant pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1406(6): For purposes of this section, "claim" does not include a contingent liability or a claim based on an event occurring after the effective date of dissolution.


Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1407 Disposition of claims by publication -- Disposition in absence of publication.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1407(1): A dissolved corporation may publish notice of its dissolution and request that persons with claims against the corporation present them in accordance with the notice.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1407(2): (1); 45-1-101 The notice contemplated in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1407(2)(a): 45-1-101 be published:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1407(2)(a)(i): one time in a newspaper of general circulation in the county where the dissolved corporation's principal office is or was located or, if it has no principal office in this state, in Salt Lake County; and
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1407(2)(a)(ii): 45-1-101 as required in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1407(2)(b): describe the information that must be included in a claim and provide an address at which any claim must be given to the corporation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1407(2)(c): state that unless sooner barred by any other statute limiting actions, the claim will be barred if an action to enforce the claim is not commenced within five years after the publication of the notice.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1407(3): (2); 16-10a-1406 If the dissolved corporation publishes a newspaper or website notice in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1407(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1407(4)(a): For purposes of this section, "claim" means any claim, including claims of this state, whether known, due or to become due, absolute or contingent, liquidated or unliquidated, founded on contract, tort, or other legal basis, or otherwise.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1407(4)(b): For purposes of this section, an action to enforce a claim includes any civil action, and any arbitration under any agreement for binding arbitration between the dissolved corporation and the claimant.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1407(5): (2); 16-10a-1406 If a dissolved corporation does not publish a newspaper notice in accordance with Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1408 Enforcement of claims against dissolved corporations.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A claim may be enforced:Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1408(1): 16-10a-1406; 16-10a-1407 under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1408(2): against a shareholder of the dissolved corporation, if the assets have been distributed in liquidation; but a shareholder's total liability for all claims under this section may not exceed the total value of assets distributed to him, as that value is determined at the time of distribution.  Any shareholder required to return any portion of the value of assets received by him in liquidation shall be entitled to contribution from all other shareholders.  The contributions shall be in accordance with the shareholders' respective rights and interests and may not exceed the value of the assets received in liquidation.


Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1409 Service on dissolved corporation.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1409(1): A dissolved corporation shall either:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1409(1)(a): maintain a registered agent in this state to accept service of process on its behalf; or
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1409(1)(b): be deemed to have authorized service of process on it by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, to the address of its principal office, if any, as set forth in its articles of dissolution or as last changed by notice delivered to the division for filing or to the address for service of process that is stated in its articles of dissolution or as last changed by notice delivered to the division for filing.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1409(2): (1)(b) Service effected pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1409(2)(a): the date the dissolved corporation receives the process, notice, or demand;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1409(2)(b): the date shown on the return receipt, if signed on behalf of the dissolved corporation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1409(2)(c): five days after mailing.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1409(3): (1) Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1420 Grounds for administrative dissolution.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
The division may commence a proceeding under SectionUtah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1420(1): the corporation does not pay when they are due any taxes, fees, or penalties imposed by this chapter or other applicable laws of this state;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1420(2): the corporation does not deliver a corporate or annual report to the division when it is due;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1420(3): the corporation is without a registered agent in this state for 30 days or more;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1420(4): the corporation does not give notice to the division within 30 days that its registered agent has been changed or that its registered agent has resigned; or
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1420(5): the corporation's period of duration stated in its articles of incorporation expires.


Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1421 Procedure for and effect of administrative dissolution.

Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1421(1): 16-10a-1420 If the division determines that one or more grounds exist under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1421(1)(a): the division's determination that one or more grounds exist for dissolving; and
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1421(1)(b): the grounds for dissolving the corporation.

Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1422 Reinstatement following dissolution.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1422(1): 16-10a-1403; 16-10a-1421; 16-10a-401 A corporation dissolved under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1422(1)(a): 16-10a-401 states:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1422(1)(a)(i): the effective date of the corporation's dissolution;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1422(1)(a)(ii): the corporation's corporate name as of the effective date of dissolution;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1422(1)(a)(iii): that the grounds for dissolution either did not exist or have been eliminated;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1422(1)(a)(iv): the corporate name under which the corporation is being reinstated;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1422(1)(a)(v): 16-10a-401 that the name stated in Subsection (1)(a)(iv) satisfies the requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1422(1)(a)(vi): that the corporation has paid all fees or penalties imposed under this chapter or other applicable state law;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1422(1)(a)(vii): that the corporation:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1422(1)(a)(vii)(A): has paid any taxes, fees, or penalties owed to the State Tax Commission; or
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1422(1)(a)(vii)(B): is current on a payment plan with the State Tax Commission for any taxes, fees, or penalties owed to the State Tax Commission;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1422(1)(a)(viii): the address of the corporation's registered office in this state;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1422(1)(a)(ix): the name of the corporation's registered agent at the office stated in Subsection (1)(a)(viii);
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1422(1)(a)(x): the federal employer identification number of the corporation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1422(1)(a)(xi): any additional information the division determines to be necessary or appropriate; and
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1422(1)(b): includes the written consent to appointment by the designated registered agent.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1422(2): 16-10a-1403; 16-10a-1421 A corporation administratively dissolved under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1422(3): 16-10a-1403; 16-10a-1421; 42-2-6.6 A corporation administratively dissolved under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1422(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1422(4)(a): After receiving a corporation's application for reinstatement, the division shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1422(4)(a)(i): provide the State Tax Commission with the corporation's federal employer identification number; and
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1422(4)(a)(ii): request that the State Tax Commission certify that the corporation is in good standing.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1422(4)(b): The State Tax Commission shall certify that a corporation is in good standing if the corporation:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1422(4)(b)(i): has paid all taxes, fees, and penalties the corporation owed to the State Tax Commission; or
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1422(4)(b)(ii): is current on a payment plan with the State Tax Commission for all taxes, fees, and penalties the corporation owes to the State Tax Commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1422(4)(c): If a corporation is not in good standing as described in Subsection (4)(b), the State Tax Commission shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1422(4)(c)(i): notify the division, stating that the corporation is not in good standing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1422(4)(c)(ii): notify the corporation, explaining in detail why the corporation is not in good standing.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1422(5): 16-10a-1421
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1422(5)(a): The division shall revoke the administrative dissolution if:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1422(5)(a)(i): the division determines that the application for reinstatement contains the information required under Subsection (1) or (2);
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1422(5)(a)(ii): the division determines that the information in the application is correct; and
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1422(5)(a)(iii): the State Tax Commission certifies that the corporation is in good standing as described in Subsection (4)(b).
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1422(5)(b): 16-10a-1421 The division shall mail to the corporation in the manner provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1422(5)(b)(i): the revocation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1422(5)(b)(ii): the effective date of the revocation.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1422(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1422(6)(a): When the reinstatement is effective, the reinstatement relates back to the effective date of the administrative dissolution.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1422(6)(b): Upon reinstatement:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1422(6)(b)(i): an act of the corporation during the period of dissolution is effective and enforceable as if the administrative dissolution had never occurred; and
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1422(6)(b)(ii): the corporation may carry on the corporation's business, under the name provided in the application for reinstatement, as if the administrative dissolution had never occurred.


Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1423 Appeal from denial of reinstatement.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
If the division denies a corporation's application for reinstatement under SectionUtah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1423(1): setting forth the reasons for denying the application; and
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1423(2): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act stating that the corporation has the right to appeal the division's determination to the executive director of the Department of Commerce in accordance with


Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1430 Grounds and procedure for judicial dissolution.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1430(1): Title 78A, Judiciary and Judicial Administration The attorney general or the division director may bring an action in a court with jurisdiction under
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1430(1)(a): the corporation obtained its articles of incorporation through fraud; or
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1430(1)(b): the corporation has continued to exceed or abuse the authority conferred upon  the corporation by law.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1430(2): Title 78A, Judiciary and Judicial Administration A shareholder may bring an action in a court with jurisdiction under
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1430(2)(a): the directors are deadlocked in the management of the corporate affairs, the shareholders are unable to break the deadlock, irreparable injury to the corporation is threatened or being suffered, or the business and affairs of the corporation can no longer be conducted to the advantage of the shareholders generally, because of the deadlock;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1430(2)(b): the directors or those in control of the corporation have acted, are acting, or will act in a manner that is illegal, oppressive, or fraudulent;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1430(2)(c): the shareholders are deadlocked in voting power and have failed, for a period that includes at least two consecutive annual meeting dates, to elect successors to directors whose terms have expired or would have expired upon the election of their successors; or
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1430(2)(d): the corporate assets are being misapplied or wasted.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1430(3): Title 78A, Judiciary and Judicial Administration A creditor may bring an action in a court with jurisdiction under
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1430(3)(a): the creditor's claim has been reduced to judgment, the execution on the judgment has been returned unsatisfied, and the corporation is insolvent; or
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1430(3)(b): the corporation is insolvent and the corporation has admitted in writing that the creditor's claim is due and owing.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1430(4): Title 78A, Judiciary and Judicial Administration A corporation may bring an action in a court with jurisdiction under
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1430(5): If an action is brought under this section, it is not necessary to make shareholders parties to the action to dissolve a corporation unless relief is sought against them individually.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1430(6): In a proceeding under this section, a court may:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1430(6)(a): issue injunctions;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1430(6)(b): appoint a receiver or custodian pendente lite with all powers and duties the court directs; or
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1430(6)(c): take other action required to preserve the corporate assets wherever located and carry on the business of the corporation until a full hearing can be held.


Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1432 Receivership or custodianship.
----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1432(1): A court in a judicial proceeding brought to dissolve a corporation may appoint one or more receivers to wind up and liquidate, or one or more custodians to manage, the business and affairs of the corporation.  The court shall hold a hearing, after giving notice to all parties to the proceeding and any interested persons designated by the court, before appointing a receiver or custodian.  The court appointing a receiver or custodian has exclusive jurisdiction over the corporation and all of its property wherever located.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1432(2): The court may appoint an individual or a domestic or foreign corporation authorized to transact business in this state as a receiver or custodian.  The court may require the receiver or custodian to post bond, with or without sureties, in an amount the court directs.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1432(3): The court shall describe the powers and duties of the receiver or custodian in its appointing order, which may be amended from time to time.  Among other powers:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1432(3)(a): the receiver:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1432(3)(a)(i): may dispose of all or any part of the assets of the corporation wherever located, at a public or private sale, if authorized by the court; and
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1432(3)(a)(ii): may sue and defend in its own name as receiver of the corporation in all courts of this state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1432(3)(b): the custodian may exercise all of the powers of the corporation, through or in place of its board of directors or officers, to the extent necessary to manage the affairs of the corporation in the best interests of its shareholders and creditors.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1432(4): The court during a receivership may redesignate the receiver a custodian, and during a custodianship may redesignate the custodian a receiver, if doing so is in the best interests of the corporation, its shareholders, and its creditors.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1432(5): The court from time to time during the receivership or custodianship may order compensation paid and expense disbursements or reimbursements made to the receiver or custodian and the custodian's or receiver's counsel from the assets of the corporation or proceeds from the sale of the assets.


Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1433 Decree of dissolution.
--------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1433(1): 16-10a-1430 If after a hearing the court determines that one or more grounds for judicial dissolution described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1433(2): 16-10a-1405; 16-10a-1406; 16-10a-1407 After entering the decree of dissolution, the court shall direct the winding up and liquidation of the corporation's business and affairs in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1433(3): The court's order may be appealed as in other civil proceedings.


Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1434 Election to purchase in lieu of dissolution.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1434(1): 16-10a-1430(2) In an action under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1434(2): 16-10a-1430(2); 16-10a-1430(2)
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1434(2)(a): 16-10a-1430(2) An election to purchase pursuant to this section may be filed with the court at any time within 90 days after the filing of the action under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1434(2)(b): If the corporation does not file an election with the court within the time period, but an election to purchase all shares of the corporation owned by the petitioning shareholder is filed by one or more shareholders within the time period, the corporation shall, within 10 days after the later of:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1434(2)(b)(i): the end of the time period allowed for the filing of elections to purchase under this section; or
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1434(2)(b)(ii): notification from the court of an election by shareholders to purchase all shares of the corporation owned by the petitioning shareholder as provided in this section, give written notice of the election to purchase to all shareholders of the corporation, other than the petitioning shareholder.  The notice shall state the name and number of shares owned by the petitioning shareholder and the name and number of shares owned by each electing shareholder.  The notice shall advise any recipients who have not participated in the election of their right to join in the election to purchase shares in accordance with this section, and of the date by which any notice of intent to participate must be filed with the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1434(2)(c): Shareholders who wish to participate in the purchase of shares from the petitioning shareholder shall file notice of their intention to join in the purchase by the electing shareholders, no later than 30 days after the effective date of the corporation's notice of their right to join in the election to purchase.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1434(2)(d): All shareholders who have filed with the court an election or notice of their intention to participate in the election to purchase the shares of the corporation owned by the petitioning shareholder thereby become irrevocably obligated to participate in the purchase of shares from the petitioning shareholders upon the terms and conditions of this section, unless the court otherwise directs.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1434(2)(e): 16-10a-1430(2) After an election has been filed by the corporation or one or more shareholders, the action under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1434(3): If, within 60 days after the earlier of:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1434(3)(a): the corporation's filing of an election to purchase all shares of the corporation owned by the petitioning shareholder; or
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1434(3)(b): the corporation's mailing of a notice to its shareholders of the filing of an election by the shareholders to purchase all shares of the corporation owned by the petitioning shareholder, the petitioning shareholder and electing corporation or shareholders reach agreement as to the fair value and terms of purchase of the petitioning shareholder's shares, the court shall enter an order directing the purchase of petitioner's shares, upon the terms and conditions agreed to by the parties.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1434(4): (3); 16-10a-1430(2); 16-10a-1430(2) If the parties are unable to reach an agreement as provided for in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1434(5): 16-10a-1430(2)(b); (d)
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1434(5)(a): Upon determining the fair value of the shares of the corporation owned by the petitioning shareholder, the court shall enter an order directing the purchase of the shares upon terms and conditions the court determines to be appropriate.  The terms and conditions may include payment of the purchase price in installments, where necessary in the interests of equity, provision for security to assure payment of the purchase price and any additional costs, fees, and expenses awarded by the court, and an allocation of shares among shareholders if the shares are to be purchased by shareholders.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1434(5)(b): In allocating the petitioning shareholders' shares among holders of different classes of shares, the court shall attempt to preserve the existing distribution of voting rights among holders of different share classes to the extent practicable.  The court may direct that holders of a specific class or classes may not participate in the purchase.  The court may not require any electing shareholder to purchase more of the shares of the corporation owned by the petitioning shareholder than the number of shares that the purchasing shareholder may have set forth in his election or notice of intent to participate filed with the court as the maximum number of shares he is willing to purchase.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1434(5)(c): Interest may be allowed at the rate and from the date determined by the court to be equitable.  However, if the court finds that the refusal of the petitioning shareholder to accept an offer of payment was arbitrary or otherwise not in good faith, interest may not be allowed.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1434(5)(d): 16-10a-1430(2)(b); (d) If the court finds that the petitioning shareholder had probable grounds for relief under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1434(6): (3); (5); 16-10a-1430 Upon entry of an order under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1434(7): (5); 16-10a-1402; 16-10a-1403; 16-10a-1405; 16-10a-1408; (5); (5)(d)
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1434(7)(a): (5); 16-10a-1402; 16-10a-1403 The purchase ordered pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1434(7)(b): 16-10a-1405; 16-10a-1408; (5); (5)(d) Upon filing of the articles of dissolution, the corporation is dissolved in accordance with the provisions of Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1434(8): (3); (5); (5)(d); 16-10a-640 Any payment by the corporation pursuant to an order under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1440 Deposit with state treasurer.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Assets of a dissolved corporation that should be transferred to a creditor, claimant, or shareholder of the corporation who cannot be found or who is not competent to receive them shall be reduced to cash and deposited with the state treasurer in accordance with

Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1501 Authority to transact business required.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1501(1): A foreign corporation may not transact business in this state until its application for authority to transact business is filed by the division.  This applies to foreign corporations that conduct a business governed by other statutes of this state only to the extent this part is not inconsistent with those other statutes.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1501(2): (1) The following, nonexhaustive list of activities does not constitute "transacting business" within the meaning of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1501(2)(a): maintaining, defending, or settling in its own behalf any legal proceeding;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1501(2)(b): holding meetings of the board of directors, shareholders, or otherwise carrying on activities concerning internal corporate affairs;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1501(2)(c): maintaining bank accounts;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1501(2)(d): maintaining offices or agencies for the transfer, exchange, and registration of its own securities or maintaining trustees or depositories with respect to those securities;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1501(2)(e): selling through independent contractors;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1501(2)(f): soliciting or obtaining orders, whether by mail or through employees or agents or otherwise, if the orders require acceptance outside this state before they become contracts;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1501(2)(g): creating as borrower or lender or acquiring indebtedness, mortgages, or security interests in real or personal property;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1501(2)(h): securing or collecting debts in its own behalf or enforcing mortgages or security interests in property securing such debts;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1501(2)(i): owning, without more, real or personal property;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1501(2)(j): conducting an isolated transaction that is completed within 30 days and that is not one in the course of repeated transactions of a like nature;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1501(2)(k): transacting business in interstate commerce;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1501(2)(l): acquiring, in transactions outside this state or in interstate commerce, of conditional sales contracts or of debts secured by mortgages or liens on real or personal property in this state, collecting or adjusting of principal or interest payments on the contracts, mortgages, or liens, enforcing or adjusting any rights provided for in conditional sales contracts or securing the described debts, taking any actions necessary to preserve and protect the interest of the conditional vendor in the property covered by a conditional sales contract or the interest of the mortgagee or holder of the lien in such security, or any combination of such transactions; and
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1501(2)(m): any other activities not considered to constitute transacting business in this state in the discretion of the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1501(3): Nothing in this section limits or affects the right to subject a foreign corporation which does not, or is not required to, have authority to transact business in this state to the jurisdiction of the courts of this state or to serve upon any foreign corporation any process, notice, or demand required or permitted by law to be served upon a corporation pursuant to any applicable provision of law or pursuant to any applicable rules of civil procedure.


Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1502 Consequences of transacting business without authority.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1502(1): A foreign corporation transacting business in this state without authority, or anyone in its behalf, may not maintain a proceeding in any court in this state until an application for authority to transact business is filed with the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1502(2): The successor to a foreign corporation that transacted business in this state without authority and the assignee of a cause of action arising out of that business may not maintain a proceeding based on that cause of action in any court in this state until an application for authority to transact business is filed on behalf of the foreign corporation or its successor.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1502(3): A court may stay a proceeding commenced by a foreign corporation, its successor, or assignee until it determines whether the foreign corporation, its successor, or assignee is required to file an application for authority to transact business. If it so determines, the court may further stay the proceeding until the required application for authority to transact business has been filed by the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1502(4): A foreign corporation that transacts business in this state without authority is subject to a civil penalty, payable to this state, of $100 for each day in which it transacts business in this state without authority. However, the penalty may not exceed a total of $5,000 for each year. Each officer of a foreign corporation who authorizes, directs, or participates in the transaction of business in this state without authority and each agent of a foreign corporation who transacts business in this state on behalf of a foreign corporation that is not authorized is subject to a civil penalty, payable to this state, not exceeding $1,000.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1502(5): (4) The civil penalties set forth in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1502(6): (1); (2) Notwithstanding Subsections


Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1503 Application for authority to transact business.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1503(1): 16-17-203(1) A foreign corporation may apply for authority to transact business in this state by delivering to the division for filing an application for authority to transact business setting forth:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1503(1)(a): its corporate name and its assumed name, if any;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1503(1)(b): the name of the state or country under whose law it is incorporated;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1503(1)(c): its date of incorporation and period of its corporate duration;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1503(1)(d): the street address of its principal office;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1503(1)(e): 16-17-203(1) the information required by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1503(1)(f): the names and usual business addresses of its current directors and officers;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1503(1)(g): the date it commenced or expects to commence transacting business in this state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1503(1)(h): any additional information the division may determine is necessary or appropriate to determine whether the application for authority to transact business should be filed.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1503(2): The foreign corporation shall deliver with the completed application for authority to transact business a certificate of existence, or a document of similar import, duly authorized by the lieutenant governor or other official having custody of corporate records in the state or country under whose law it is incorporated.  The certificate of existence shall be dated within 90 days before the day on which the application for authority to transact business by the division is filed.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1503(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1503(3)(a): The division may permit a tribal corporation to apply for authority to transact business in this state in the same manner as a foreign corporation incorporated in another state.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1503(3)(b): If a tribal corporation elects to apply for authority to transact business in this state, for purposes of this chapter, the tribal corporation shall be treated in the same manner as a foreign corporation incorporated under the laws of another state.


Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1504 Amended application for authority to transact business.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1504(1): 16-17-203(1) A foreign corporation authorized to transact business in this state shall deliver an amended application for authority to transact business to the division for filing if the foreign corporation changes:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1504(1)(a): its corporate name or its assumed corporate name;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1504(1)(b): the period of its duration;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1504(1)(c): the state or country of its incorporation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1504(1)(d): 16-17-203(1) any of the information required by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1504(2): 16-10a-1503 The requirements of Section


Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1505 Effect of filing an application for authority to transact business.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1505(1): Filing an application for authority to transact business authorizes the foreign corporation to transact business in this state subject, however, to the right of the state to revoke the certificate as provided in this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1505(2): A foreign corporation authorized to transact business in this state has the same rights and privileges as, but no greater rights or privileges than, a domestic corporation of like character. Except as otherwise provided by this chapter, a foreign corporation authorized to transact business in this state is subject to the same duties, restrictions, penalties, and liabilities now or later imposed on a domestic corporation of like character.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1505(3): This chapter does not authorize this state to regulate the organization or internal affairs of a foreign corporation authorized to transact business in this state.


Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1506 Corporate name and assumed corporate name of foreign corporation.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1506(1): (2); 16-10a-401; 16-10a-401 Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1506(2): (1); 16-10a-401(2) A foreign corporation may obtain authority to transact business in this state with a name that does not meet the requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1506(2)(a): a written consent to the foreign corporation's use of the name, given and signed by the other person entitled to the use of the name together with a written undertaking by the other person, in a form satisfactory to the division, to change its name to a name that is distinguishable from the name of the applicant; or
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1506(2)(b): a certified copy of a final judgment of a court of competent jurisdiction establishing the prior right of the foreign corporation to use the requested name in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1506(3): A foreign corporation may use in this state the name, including the fictitious name, of another domestic or foreign corporation that is used or registered in this state if the other corporation is incorporated or authorized to transact business in this state and the foreign corporation:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1506(3)(a): has merged with the other corporation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1506(3)(b): has been formed by reorganization of the other corporation.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1506(4): (1); (3); 16-10a-401; 16-10a-1504 If a foreign corporation authorized to transact business in this state, whether under its corporate name or an assumed corporate name, changes its corporate name to one that does not satisfy the requirements of Subsections


Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1507 Registered name of foreign corporation.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1507(1): 16-10a-401; 16-10a-401 A foreign corporation may register its corporate name as provided in this section if the name would be available for use as a corporate name for a domestic corporation under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1507(2): (1); 16-10a-401 A foreign corporation registers its corporate name, or its corporate name with any addition permitted by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1507(2)(a): 16-10a-401 setting forth its corporate name, the name to be registered which shall meet the requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10a-1507(2)(b): accompanied by a certificate of existence, or a document of similar import from the state or country of incorporation as evidence that the foreign corporation is in existence or has authority to transact business under the laws of the state or country in which it is organized.
