Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-106(3): A sale, lease, exchange, or other disposition of all or substantially all of the assets of a benefit corporation, unless the transaction is in the usual and regular course of business, is not effective unless the transaction is approved by at least the minimum status vote.


Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-201 Corporate purposes.
----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-201(1): 16-10a-301 A benefit corporation shall have a purpose of creating general public benefit.  This purpose is in addition to its purpose under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-201(2): 16-10a-301; (1); (2); (1) The articles of incorporation of a benefit corporation may identify one or more specific public benefits that it is the purpose of the benefit corporation to create in addition to its purposes under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-201(3): (1); (2) The creation of general public benefit and a specific public benefit under Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-201(4): A benefit corporation may amend its articles of incorporation to add, amend, or delete the identification of a specific public benefit that it is the purpose of the benefit corporation to create.  To be effective, the amendment must be adopted by at least the minimum status vote.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-201(5): 16-11-6 A professional corporation that is a benefit corporation does not violate Section


Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-301 Standard of conduct for directors.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-301(1): (2) Subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-301(1)(a): shall consider the effects of an action or inaction upon:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-301(1)(a)(i): the shareholders of the benefit corporation;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-301(1)(a)(ii): the employees and workforce of the benefit corporation, its subsidiaries, and its suppliers;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-301(1)(a)(iii): the interests of customers as beneficiaries of the general public benefit or specific public benefit purposes of the benefit corporation;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-301(1)(a)(iv): community and societal factors, including those of each community in which offices or facilities of the benefit corporation, its subsidiaries, or its suppliers are located;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-301(1)(a)(v): the local and global environment;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-301(1)(a)(vi): the short-term and long-term interests of the benefit corporation, including benefits that may accrue to the benefit corporation from its long-term plans and the possibility that these interests may be best served by the continued independence of the benefit corporation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-301(1)(a)(vii): the ability of the benefit corporation to accomplish its general public benefit purpose and a specific public benefit purpose; and
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-301(1)(b): may consider other pertinent factors or the interests of any other group that they consider appropriate.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-301(2): (2)(b); (1); (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-301(2)(a): (2)(b); (1) Subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-301(2)(b): (2)(a) Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-301(3): (1); (2); 16-10a-840 The consideration of interests and factors in the manner required by Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-301(4): (1); (2); 16-10a-840 Except as provided in the articles of incorporation or bylaws, a director is not personally liable for monetary damages for:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-301(4)(a): (1); (2); 16-10a-840 an action or inaction in the course of performing the duties of a director under Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-301(4)(b): failure of the benefit corporation to pursue or create general public benefit or specific public benefit.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-301(5): A director does not have a duty to a person that is a beneficiary of the general public benefit purpose or a specific public benefit purpose of a benefit corporation arising from the status of the person as a beneficiary.


Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-302 Benefit director.
--------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-302(1): The board of directors of a benefit corporation that is a publicly traded corporation shall, and the board of directors of any other benefit corporation may, include a director, who:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-302(1)(a): is designated the benefit director; and
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-302(1)(b): shall have, in addition to the powers, duties, rights, and immunities of the other directors of the benefit corporation, the powers, duties, rights, and immunities provided in this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-302(2): 16-10a-801; 16-10a-810; (6); (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-302(2)(a): 16-10a-801; 16-10a-810 A benefit director shall be elected, and may be removed, in the manner provided by Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-302(2)(b): (6) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-302(2)(c): The benefit director may serve as the benefit officer at the same time as serving as the benefit director.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-302(2)(d): (2) The articles of incorporation or bylaws of a benefit corporation may prescribe additional qualifications of the benefit director not inconsistent with this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-302(3): 16-10b-401; 16-10b-301(1); 16-10b-303(1); (3)(a); (b) The benefit director shall prepare, and the benefit corporation shall include in the annual benefit report to shareholders required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-302(3)(a): whether the benefit corporation acted in accordance with its general public benefit purpose and any specific public benefit purpose in all material respects during the period covered by the report;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-302(3)(b): 16-10b-301(1); 16-10b-303(1) whether the directors and officers complied with Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-302(3)(c): (3)(a); (b) if, in the opinion of the benefit director, the benefit corporation or its directors or officers failed to act or comply in the manner described in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-302(4): The act or inaction of an individual in the capacity of a benefit director shall constitute for all purposes an act or inaction of that individual in the capacity of a director of the benefit corporation.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-302(5): 16-10a-841 Regardless of whether the articles of incorporation or bylaws of a benefit corporation include a provision eliminating or limiting the personal liability of directors authorized by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-302(6): The benefit director of a professional corporation does not need to be independent.


Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-303 Standard of conduct for officers.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-303(1): 16-10b-301(1); 16-10b-301(1); (2) An officer of a benefit corporation shall consider the interests and factors described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-303(1)(a): the officer has discretion to act with respect to a matter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-303(1)(b): it reasonably appears to the officer that the matter may have a material effect on the creation by the benefit corporation of general public benefit or a specific public benefit identified in the articles of incorporation of the benefit corporation.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-303(2): (1); 16-10a-831; 16-10a-840 The consideration of interests and factors in the manner described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-303(3): (1); 16-10a-831; 16-10a-840 Except as provided in the articles of incorporation or bylaws of a benefit corporation, an officer is not personally liable for monetary damages for:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-303(3)(a): (1); 16-10a-831; 16-10a-840 an action or inaction as an officer in the course of performing the duties of an officer under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-303(3)(b): failure of the benefit corporation to pursue or create general public benefit or specific public benefit.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-303(4): An officer does not have a duty to a person that is a beneficiary of the general public benefit purpose or a specific public benefit purpose of a benefit corporation arising from the status of the person as a beneficiary.


Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-304 Benefit officer.
-------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-304(1): A benefit corporation may have an officer designated as the benefit officer.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-304(2): 16-10b-401 A benefit officer has:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-304(2)(a): the powers and duties relating to the purpose of the corporation to create general public benefit or specific public benefit provided:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-304(2)(a)(i): by the bylaws; or
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-304(2)(a)(ii): absent controlling provisions in the bylaws, by resolutions or orders of the board of directors; and
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-304(2)(b): 16-10b-401 the duty to prepare the benefit report required by Section


Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-305 Right of action.
-------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-305(1): Except in a benefit enforcement proceeding, a person may not bring an action or assert a claim against a benefit corporation or its directors or officers with respect to:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-305(1)(a): failure to pursue or create general public benefit or a specific public benefit set forth in its articles of incorporation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-305(1)(b): violation of an obligation, duty, or standard of conduct under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-305(2): A benefit corporation may not be liable for monetary damages under this chapter for a failure of the benefit corporation to pursue or create general public benefit or a specific public benefit.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-305(3): (3)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-305(3)(a): A benefit enforcement proceeding may be commenced or maintained only:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-305(3)(a)(i): directly by the benefit corporation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-305(3)(a)(ii): derivatively by:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-305(3)(a)(ii)(A): a person or group of persons that owns beneficially or of record at least 2% of the total number of shares of a class or series outstanding at the time of the act or omission complained of;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-305(3)(a)(ii)(B): a director;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-305(3)(a)(ii)(C): a person or group of persons that own beneficially or of record 5% or more of the outstanding equity interests in an entity of which the benefit corporation is a subsidiary at the time of the act or omission complained of; or
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-305(3)(a)(ii)(D): other persons as specified in the articles of incorporation or bylaws of the benefit corporation.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-305(3)(b): (3)(a) A benefit corporation may provide in its articles of incorporation a greater degree of ownership by a person or group of persons than those listed under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-305(4): For purposes of this section, a person is the beneficial owner of shares or equity interests if the shares or equity interests are held in a voting trust or by a nominee on behalf of the beneficial owner.


Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-401 Preparation of annual benefit report.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-401(1): 16-10b-302(3) A benefit corporation shall prepare an annual benefit report that includes all of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-401(1)(a): a narrative description of:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-401(1)(a)(i): the ways in which the benefit corporation pursued general public benefit during the year and the extent to which general public benefit was created;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-401(1)(a)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-401(1)(a)(ii)(A): the ways in which the benefit corporation pursued a specific public benefit that the articles of incorporation state it is the purpose of the benefit corporation to create; and
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-401(1)(a)(ii)(B): the extent to which that specific public benefit was created; and
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-401(1)(a)(iii): circumstances that have hindered the creation by the benefit corporation of general public benefit or specific public benefit;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-401(1)(b): an assessment of the overall social and environmental performance of the benefit corporation against a third-party standard:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-401(1)(b)(i): applied consistently with the application of that third-party standard in prior benefit reports; or
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-401(1)(b)(ii): accompanied by an explanation of the reasons for an inconsistent application;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-401(1)(c): the name of the benefit director and the benefit officer, if any, and the address to which correspondence to each of them may be directed;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-401(1)(d): 16-10b-302(3) the statement of the benefit director described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-401(1)(e): an identification of the third-party standard that will be used to prepare the next benefit report of the benefit corporation and a discussion of:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-401(1)(e)(i): the process and rationale for selecting that third-party standard and, if it is different from the previous third-party standard used by the benefit corporation, the reasons for the change; and
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-401(1)(e)(ii): any connection between the organization that established the third-party standard, or its directors, officers, or a holder of 5% or more of the governance interests in the organization, and the benefit corporation or its directors, officers, or a holder of 5% or more of the outstanding shares of the benefit corporation, including a financial or governance relationship that might materially affect the credibility of the use of the third-party standard; and
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-401(1)(f): if the benefit corporation has dispensed with, or restricted the discretion or powers of, the board of directors, a description of the persons that exercise the powers, duties, and rights and who have the immunities of the board of directors.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-401(2): If, during the year covered by a benefit report, a benefit director resigns, refuses to stand for reelection to the position of benefit director, or is removed from the position of benefit director, and the benefit director furnishes the benefit corporation with written correspondence concerning the circumstances surrounding the resignation, refusal, or removal, the benefit report shall include that correspondence as an exhibit.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-401(3): (1)(b) Neither the benefit report nor the assessment of the performance of the benefit corporation in the benefit report required by Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-402 Availability of annual benefit report.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-402(1): 16-10b-401 A benefit corporation shall send its annual benefit report required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-402(1)(a): 120 days following the end of the fiscal year of the benefit corporation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-402(1)(b): the same time that the benefit corporation delivers another annual report to its shareholders.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-402(2): A benefit corporation shall post all of its annual benefit reports on the public portion of its Internet website, if any, but financial or proprietary information included in the annual benefit reports may be omitted from the annual benefit reports as posted.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-402(3): If a benefit corporation does not have an Internet website, the benefit corporation shall provide a copy of its most recent annual benefit report, without charge, to a person that requests a copy, but financial or proprietary information included in the annual benefit report may be omitted from the copy of the benefit report provided.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-402(4): 16-10a-1607; 63J-1-504; 16-10a-1607
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-402(4)(a): 16-10a-1607 At the same time that the benefit corporation files its annual report with the division in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-402(4)(b): 63J-1-504 The division shall charge a fee established by the division in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-10b-402(4)(c): 16-10a-1607 The benefit corporation shall file the annual benefit report in addition to the annual report required by Section


Utah Code Annotated - Title 16 - Chapter 11 - Professional Corporation Act
**************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-1 Short title.
------------------------------------------
This act shall be known and may be cited as the "Professional Corporation Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-2 Definitions.
------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-2(1): "Filed" means the division has received and approved, as to form, a document submitted under this chapter, and has marked on the face of the document a stamp or seal indicating the time of day and date of approval, the name of the division, the division director's signature and division seal, or facsimiles of the signature or seal.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-2(2): "Professional corporation" means a corporation organized under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-2(3): Title 58, Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act; Title 58, Chapter 69, Dentist and Dental Hygienist Practice Act; Title 58, Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act; Title 58, Chapter 70a, Utah Physician Assistant Act; Title 58, Chapter 73, Chiropractic Physician Practice Act; Title 58, Chapter 5a, Podiatric Physician Licensing Act; Title 58, Chapter 16a, Utah Optometry Practice Act; Title 58, Chapter 28, Veterinary Practice Act; Title 58, Chapter 3a, Architects Licensing Act; Title 58, Chapter 26a, Certified Public Accountant Licensing Act; Title 58, Chapter 71, Naturopathic Physician Practice Act; Title 58, Chapter 17b, Pharmacy Practice Act; Title 58, Chapter 22, Professional Engineers and Professional Land Surveyors Licensing Act; Title 61, Chapter 2f, Real Estate Licensing and Practices Act; Title 58, Chapter 61, Psychologist Licensing Act; Title 58, Chapter 60, Part 2, Social Worker Licensing Act; Title 58, Chapter 24b, Physical Therapy Practice Act; Title 58, Chapter 31b, Nurse Practice Act; Title 58, Chapter 44a, Nurse Midwife Practice Act; Title 58, Chapter 53, Landscape Architects Licensing Act; Title 61, Chapter 2g, Real Estate Appraiser Licensing and Certification Act "Professional service" means the personal service rendered by:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-2(3)(a): Title 58, Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act a physician, surgeon, or doctor of medicine holding a license under
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-2(3)(b): Title 58, Chapter 69, Dentist and Dental Hygienist Practice Act a doctor of dentistry holding a license under
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-2(3)(c): Title 58, Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act an osteopathic physician or surgeon holding a license under
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-2(3)(d): Title 58, Chapter 70a, Utah Physician Assistant Act a physician assistant holding a license under
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-2(3)(e): Title 58, Chapter 73, Chiropractic Physician Practice Act a chiropractor holding a license under
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-2(3)(f): Title 58, Chapter 5a, Podiatric Physician Licensing Act a podiatric physician holding a license under
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-2(3)(g): Title 58, Chapter 16a, Utah Optometry Practice Act an optometrist holding a license under
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-2(3)(h): Title 58, Chapter 28, Veterinary Practice Act a veterinarian holding a license under
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-2(3)(i): Title 58, Chapter 3a, Architects Licensing Act an architect holding a license under
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-2(3)(j): Title 58, Chapter 26a, Certified Public Accountant Licensing Act a public accountant holding a license under
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-2(3)(k): Title 58, Chapter 71, Naturopathic Physician Practice Act a naturopath holding a license under
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-2(3)(l): Title 58, Chapter 17b, Pharmacy Practice Act a pharmacist holding a license under
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-2(3)(m): an attorney granted the authority to practice law by:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-2(3)(m)(i): the Utah Supreme Court; or
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-2(3)(m)(ii): the Supreme Court, other court, agency, instrumentality, or regulating board that licenses or regulates the authority to practice law in any state or territory of the United States other than Utah;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-2(3)(n): Title 58, Chapter 22, Professional Engineers and Professional Land Surveyors Licensing Act a professional engineer registered under
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-2(3)(o): Title 61, Chapter 2f, Real Estate Licensing and Practices Act a principal broker, associate broker, or sales agent holding a license under
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-2(3)(p): Title 58, Chapter 61, Psychologist Licensing Act a psychologist holding a license under
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-2(3)(q): Title 58, Chapter 60, Part 2, Social Worker Licensing Act a clinical or certified social worker holding a license under
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-2(3)(r): Title 58, Chapter 24b, Physical Therapy Practice Act a physical therapist holding a license under
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-2(3)(s): Title 58, Chapter 31b, Nurse Practice Act; Title 58, Chapter 44a, Nurse Midwife Practice Act a nurse licensed under
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-2(3)(t): Title 58, Chapter 53, Landscape Architects Licensing Act a landscape architect licensed under
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-2(3)(u): Title 61, Chapter 2g, Real Estate Appraiser Licensing and Certification Act an individual licensed, certified, or registered under
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-2(4): Title 16, Chapter 10a, Utah Revised Business Corporation Act "Regulating board" means the board that is charged with the licensing and regulation of the practice of the profession which the professional corporation is organized to render.  The definitions of


Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-3 Purpose of act.
---------------------------------------------
This act shall be so construed as to effectuate its general purpose of making available to professional persons the benefits of the corporate form for the business aspects of their practices while preserving the established professional aspects of the personal relationship between the professional person and those he serves.

Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-4 Incorporators -- Articles of incorporation.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-4(1): One or more individuals, each of whom is licensed to render a professional service, may incorporate a professional corporation by filing articles of incorporation with the Division of Corporations and Commercial Code.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-4(2): (1); Title 16, Chapter 10a, Utah Revised Business Corporation Act Articles of incorporation under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-4(2)(a): the profession to be practiced through the professional corporation;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-4(2)(b): the names and street or mailing addresses of all of the original shareholders, directors, and officers of the professional corporation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-4(2)(c): the number of shareholder members of the board of directors may be less than the number of shareholders, except if a corporation has only one shareholder, the board may consist of that shareholder.


Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-5 Application of Utah Revised Business Corporation Act -- Conflicts.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The provisions of

Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-6 Purpose of professional corporation -- Power to own property and invest funds.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-6(1): A professional corporation may be organized pursuant to the provisions of this chapter only for the purpose of rendering one specific type of professional service and services ancillary to the specific type of professional service and may not engage in any business other than rendering the professional service that it was organized to render and services ancillary to the specific type of professional service.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-6(2): (1); Chapter 10b, Benefit Corporation Act Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-6(2)(a): own real and personal property necessary or appropriate for rendering the type of professional service it was organized to render;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-6(2)(b): invest its funds in real estate, mortgages, stocks, bonds, and any other type of investments; and
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-6(2)(c): Chapter 10b, Benefit Corporation Act if a benefit corporation, have as a purpose creating a general public benefit and a specific public benefit as provided in


Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-7 Issuance of shares of capital stock -- Restrictions.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-7(1): (1)(a) A professional corporation may issue the shares of its capital stock and a shareholder may voluntarily transfer shares of capital stock in a professional corporation only to:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-7(1)(a): persons who are duly licensed to render the same specific professional services as those for which the corporation was organized; or
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-7(1)(b): (1)(a) persons other than those meeting the requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-7(2): Any shares issued in violation of this section are void.


Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-8 Officer, director, or shareholder shall be licensed professional -- Nonlicensed person as secretary or treasurer.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-8(1): (1)(b); (1)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-8(1)(a): (1)(b) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-8(1)(a)(i): an individual licensed to render the same specific professional services as those for which the corporation is organized; or
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-8(1)(a)(ii): qualified to be an officer, director, or shareholder under the applicable licensing act for the profession for which the corporation is organized.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-8(1)(b): (1)(a) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-8(2): (1); Title 58, Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act; Title 58, Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act; (2)(a) For purposes of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-8(2)(a): Title 58, Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act; Title 58, Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act the corporation is organized to provide services described in:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-8(2)(a)(i): Title 58, Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-8(2)(a)(ii): Title 58, Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-8(2)(b): (2)(a) the officer, director, or shareholder is licensed under either of the chapters listed in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-9 Licensed persons to render professional services.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A professional corporation may render professional services only through its officers, employees and agents who are duly licensed to render such professional services.

Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-10 Laws as to professional relationships not altered.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
This act does not alter any law applicable to the relationship between a person rendering professional services and a person receiving such services, including liability arising out of such professional services.

Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-11 Authority of regulating boards not restricted or limited.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Nothing in this act shall restrict or limit in any manner the authority and duty of the regulating board for the licensing of individual persons rendering professional services or the practice of the profession which is within the jurisdiction of such regulating board, notwithstanding that such person is an officer, director, shareholder or employee of a professional corporation and rendering such professional services or engaging in the practice of such profession through such professional corporation.

Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-12 Prohibited acts of professional corporations.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
No professional corporation may do any act which is prohibited to be done by individual persons licensed to practice the profession which the professional corporation is organized to render.

Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-13 Purchase or redemption of shares of disqualified shareholder.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-13(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-13(1)(a): The articles of incorporation may provide for the purchase or redemption of the shares of any shareholder upon the failure to qualify or disqualification of that shareholder, or the same may be provided in the bylaws or by private agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-13(1)(b): In the absence of such a provision in the articles of incorporation, the bylaws, or by private agreement, the professional corporation shall purchase the shares of a shareholder who is not qualified to own shares in the corporation within 90 days after the failure to qualify or disqualification of the shareholder.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-13(2): The price for shares purchased under this section shall be their reasonable fair value as of the date of failure to qualify or disqualification of the shareholder.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-13(3): (1); Title 78A, Judiciary and Judicial Administration; (3)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-13(3)(a): (1); Title 78A, Judiciary and Judicial Administration If the professional corporation fails to purchase shares as required by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-13(3)(b): (3)(a) In an action under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-13(3)(b)(i): award the plaintiff the reasonable fair value of the plaintiff's shares; or
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-13(3)(b)(ii): within the court's jurisdiction, order the liquidation of the professional corporation.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-13(3)(c): If the plaintiff is successful in the action, the plaintiff is entitled to recover a reasonable attorney's fee and costs.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-13(4): Title 16, Chapter 10a, Utah Revised Business Corporation Act The professional corporation shall repurchase shares as required by this section without regard to restrictions upon the repurchase of shares provided by


Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-14 Annual certificate -- Filing -- Contents -- Filing fee.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
During the month of the anniversary date of incorporation, each professional corporation shall file with the division an annual report as specified by Section

Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-15 Incorporation under Utah Revised Business Corporation Act permitted -- Existing corporations may come under Professional Corporation Act.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
This act does not preclude incorporation by professional persons under

Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16 Corporate name.
----------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(1): 16-11-6 The name of each professional corporation as set forth in the professional corporation's articles of incorporation:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(1)(a): shall contain the terms:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(1)(a)(i): "professional corporation"; or
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(1)(a)(ii): "P.C.";
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(1)(b): may not contain the words:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(1)(b)(i): "incorporated"; or
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(1)(b)(ii): "inc.";
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(1)(c): 16-11-6 may not contain:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(1)(c)(i): 16-11-6 language stating or implying that the professional corporation is organized for a purpose other than that permitted by:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(1)(c)(i)(A): 16-11-6 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(1)(c)(i)(B): the professional corporation's articles of incorporation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(1)(c)(ii): for a professional corporation that changes the professional corporation's name or is incorporated in or authorized to do business in the state on or after May 4, 2022, the number sequence "911"; and
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(1)(d): without the written consent of the United States Olympic Committee, may not contain the words:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(1)(d)(i): "Olympic";
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(1)(d)(ii): "Olympiad"; or
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(1)(d)(iii): "Citius Altius Fortius".
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(2): The professional corporation may not imply by any word in the name that the professional corporation is an agency of the state or of any of the state's political subdivisions.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(3): A person, other than a professional corporation formed or registered under this chapter, may not use in the person's name in this state any of the terms:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(3)(a): "professional corporation"; or
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(3)(b): "P.C."
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(4): (5); (6) Except as authorized by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(4)(a): the name of any domestic corporation incorporated in or foreign corporation authorized to transact business in this state;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(4)(b): the name of any domestic or foreign nonprofit corporation incorporated or authorized to transact business in this state;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(4)(c): the name of any domestic or foreign limited liability company formed or authorized to transact business in this state;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(4)(d): the name of any limited partnership formed or authorized to transact business in this state;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(4)(e): any name reserved or registered with the division for a corporation, limited liability company, or general or limited partnership, under the laws of this state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(4)(f): any business name, fictitious name, assumed name, trademark, or service mark registered by the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(5): (4); (5)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(5)(a): (4) A professional corporation may apply to the division for authorization to file the professional corporation's articles of incorporation under, or to register or reserve, a name that is not distinguishable upon the division's records from one or more of the names described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(5)(b): (5)(a) The division shall approve the application filed under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(5)(b)(i): the other person whose name is not distinguishable from the name under which the applicant desires to file, or which the applicant desires to register or reserve:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(5)(b)(i)(A): consents to the filing, registration, or reservation in writing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(5)(b)(i)(B): submits an undertaking in a form satisfactory to the division to change the person's name to a name that is distinguishable from the name of the applicant; or
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(5)(b)(ii): the applicant delivers to the division a certified copy of the final judgment of a court of competent jurisdiction establishing the applicant's right to make the requested filing in this state under the name applied for.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(6)(a): A name is distinguishable from other names, trademarks, and service marks registered with the division if the name:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(6)(a)(i): contains one or more different letters or numerals from other names upon the division's records; or
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(6)(a)(ii): has a different sequence of letter or numerals from the other names on the division's records.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(6)(b): The following differences are not distinguishable:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(6)(b)(i): the words or abbreviations of the words:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(6)(b)(i)(A): "corporation";
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(6)(b)(i)(B): "incorporated";
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(6)(b)(i)(C): "company";
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(6)(b)(i)(D): "limited partnership";
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(6)(b)(i)(E): "limited";
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(6)(b)(i)(F): "L.P.";
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(6)(b)(i)(G): "limited liability company";
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(6)(b)(i)(H): "limited company";
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(6)(b)(i)(I): "L.C."; or
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(6)(b)(i)(J): "L.L.C.";
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(6)(b)(ii): the presence or absence of the words or symbols of the words "the," "and," "a," or "plus";
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(6)(b)(iii): differences in punctuation and special characters;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(6)(b)(iv): differences in capitalization; or
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(6)(b)(v): differences in abbreviations.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-11-16(7): The director of the division shall have the power and authority reasonably necessary to interpret and efficiently administer this section and to perform the duties imposed upon the division by this section.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 16 - Chapter 12 - Real Estate Investment Trust Act
******************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 16-12-1 Short title.
------------------------------------------
This act shall be known and cited as the "Real Estate Investment Trust Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 16-12-2 Definition of real estate investment trust.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
A real estate investment trust is an unincorporated trust or association which has complied or intends to comply with Sections 856, 857, and 858 of the federal Internal Revenue Code of 1954, as amended, or such sections or section of any subsequent internal revenue code as may be applicable to organizations described in Public Law 86-779.

Utah Code Annotated § 16-12-3 Declaration of trust -- Filing fee.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
An original and one copy of the declaration of trust of a real estate investment trust shall be delivered to the Division of Corporations and Commercial Code, and the division shall endorse on the original and one copy the word "filed."  The Division of Corporations and Commercial Code shall file the original in the division's office, and shall return the copy to the trustees or their representatives.  The Division of Corporations and Commercial Code may charge a fee pursuant to Section

Utah Code Annotated § 16-12-4 Powers of real estate investment trust.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
A real estate investment trust shall have power to sue and be sued, in its trust name, and to acquire title, lease, mortgage, convey or otherwise deal with real and personal property, or any interest therein in its trust name.

Utah Code Annotated § 16-12-5 Limited liability of shareholders or beneficiaries.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The shareholders or beneficiaries of a real estate investment trust are not, as such, personally liable for obligations of the real estate investment trust, and shall be under no obligation to the trust or its creditors with respect to such shares or interest other than the obligation to pay the trust the full amount of consideration for which such shares were issued or to be issued.

Utah Code Annotated § 16-12-6 Trustee governed by declaration of trust -- Liability.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A trustee of a real estate investment trust shall be governed by all the provisions of the declaration of trust and is not liable for any claims or damages that may result from his acts in the discharge of any duty imposed or power conferred upon him by the trust, if he exercises ordinary care, and acts in good faith, but shall be liable for his own willful misfeasance or malfeasance.  Persons dealing with the trust through the trustees or agents shall look to the trust estate for performance of obligations.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 16 - Chapter 13 - Business Development Corporations
*******************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 16-13-1 Organization of development corporations under Utah Revised Business Corporation Act -- Corporate name.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Corporations to conduct a development business as specified in this act may be formed under the provisions of

Utah Code Annotated § 16-13-2 Definitions.
------------------------------------------
As used in this act:Utah Code Annotated § 16-13-2(1): The words "financial institution" mean any corporation engaged in a banking business, loan and trust company, or corporation, partnership, foundation, or other institution engaged primarily in lending or investing funds.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-13-2(2): The word "lender" means any person, partnership, association, corporation including any financial institution and any corporation, agency or instrumentality organized or authorized by an act of Congress which lends money to a corporation organized in accordance with this act upon its call and in accordance with the provisions of this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-13-2(3): The words "loan limit" mean for any lender the total of the maximum amount prescribed to be outstanding at one time on loans made by such lender to a corporation organized under this act and the amount of the investment in the capital stock of such corporation then held by such lender, as determined under the provisions of this act, and the amount of the investment in the capital stock of such corporation then held by such lender, as determined under the provisions of this act.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-13-2(4): The words "development corporation" means a corporation organized in accordance with the provisions of this act.


Utah Code Annotated § 16-13-3 Purposes of development corporation.
------------------------------------------------------------------
The purposes of a development corporation shall include the following:

Utah Code Annotated § 16-13-4 General powers of business development corporation.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
In furtherance of the purposes of a development corporation, and in addition to the powers conferred on corporations byUtah Code Annotated § 16-13-4(1): To borrow money from lenders, and otherwise incur indebtedness for any of its purposes; to issue its bonds, debentures, notes, or other evidences of indebtedness whether secured or unsecured therefor; and to secure the same by mortgage, pledge, deed of trust, or other lien on its property, franchises, rights and privileges of every kind and nature or any part thereof.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-13-4(2): To lend money to, and to guarantee, indorse, or act as surety on the bonds, notes, contracts, or other obligations of, or otherwise assist financially, any person, firm, corporation, or association, and to establish and regulate the terms and conditions with respect to any such loans or financial assistance and the charges for interest and service connected therewith; provided, however, that the corporation may not approve any application for a loan unless and until the applicant shall have shown that the applicant has applied for the loan through ordinary financial channels and that the loan has been refused by at least one financial institution doing business in this state and, in the ordinary course of its business, granting loans similar in amount and kind to the requested loan.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-13-4(3): To purchase, receive, hold, lease, or otherwise acquire, and to sell, convey, mortgage, lease, pledge, or otherwise dispose of, upon such terms and conditions as its board of directors may deem advisable, real and personal property, together with such rights and privileges as may be incidental and appurtenant thereto and the use thereof, including, but not restricted to, any real or personal property acquired by such corporation from time to time in the satisfaction of debts or enforcement of obligations.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-13-4(4): To acquire the good will, business, rights, real and personal property, and other assets, or any part thereof, of such persons, firms, corporations, joint stock companies, associations, or trusts as may be in furtherance of the corporate purposes provided herein, and to assume, undertake, guarantee, or pay the obligations, debts, and liabilities of any such person, firm, corporation, joint stock company, association, or trust; to acquire improved or unimproved real estate for the purpose of constructing industrial plants or other business establishments thereon or for the purpose of disposing of such real estate to others for the construction of industrial plants or other business establishments, and, in furtherance of the corporate purposes, to acquire, construct, or reconstruct, alter, repair, maintain, operate, sell, lease, or otherwise dispose of industrial plants or business establishments.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-13-4(5): To acquire, subscribe for, own, hold, sell, assign, transfer, mortgage, pledge, or otherwise dispose of the stock, shares, bonds, debentures, notes, or other securities and evidences of interest in, or indebtedness of, any person, firm, corporation, joint stock company, association, or trust, and while the owner or holder thereof, to exercise all the rights, powers, and privileges of ownership, including the right to vote thereon, but nothing herein provided shall authorize the holding of securities of or otherwise engaging directly or indirectly in a business where such holding of securities or engaging in business is not authorized for corporations by general law.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-13-4(6): To cooperate with and avail itself of the facilities of state departments and other government agencies; and to cooperate with and assist, and otherwise encourage, local organizations in the various communities in the state in the promotion, assistance, and development of the business prosperity and economic welfare of such communities and of the state.


Utah Code Annotated § 16-13-5 Bonds or securities, capital stock of development corporations -- Authority to purchase, hold, or dispose of -- Rights of holders -- Rights of financial institutions.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-13-5(1): All persons, firms, partnerships, associations, trusts and domestic and foreign corporations organized or authorized to do business in this state, including, without implied limitation, all financial institutions, public utility corporations and insurance corporations, are hereby authorized to acquire, purchase, hold, sell, assign, transfer, mortgage, pledge, or otherwise dispose of any bonds, securities or other evidences of indebtedness created by a development corporation, and to exercise all the rights, powers and privileges of ownership thereof, all without the approval of any regulatory authority of the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-13-5(2): All persons, firms, partnerships, associations, trusts, domestic and foreign corporations organized or authorized to do business in this state, including without implied limitation all public utility corporations and insurance corporations, other than financial institutions, are hereby authorized to acquire, purchase, hold, sell, assign, transfer, mortgage, pledge, or otherwise dispose of any of the shares of the capital stock of a development corporation, and while owners of said stock to exercise all the rights, powers and privileges of ownership, including the right to vote thereon, all without the approval of any regulatory authority of the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-13-5(3): All financial institutions are hereby authorized to become lenders to development corporations and to make loans to the corporations as provided herein, without the approval of any regulatory authority of the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-13-5(4): A financial institution is authorized to acquire, purchase, hold, sell, assign, transfer, mortgage, pledge, or otherwise dispose of, any bonds, securities or other evidences of indebtedness created by the corporation in accordance with its provisions for the call of loans, and any of the shares of the capital stock of the corporation, and while owners thereof, to exercise all the rights, powers and privileges of ownership, including the right to vote, all without approval of any regulatory authority of the state; provided, that the amount of the capital stock of the corporation which may be acquired by any lender pursuant to the authority granted herein may not exceed 10% of the loan limit of such lender.  The amount of capital stock of the corporation which any lender is authorized to acquire pursuant to the authority granted herein is in addition to the amount of capital stock in corporations which such lender may otherwise be authorized to acquire.


Utah Code Annotated § 16-13-8 Board of directors -- Number and election of members.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The board of directors of a development corporation shall be of such number in multiples of three, but not less than six, as shall be determined in the first instance by the articles of incorporation and thereafter annually by the stockholders of the corporation. The names and addresses of the members of the first board of directors shall be stated in the articles of incorporation. Said persons shall hold office until the first annual meeting of the corporation and until their successors have been elected and qualified. At the first annual meeting of a development corporation and at each annual meeting thereafter, or, if no annual meeting shall be held in any year at the time fixed by the bylaws, at a special meeting held in lieu thereof, the shareholders shall elect the directors. The directors shall hold office until the next annual meeting, after their elections, and until their successors are elected and qualified unless sooner removed.

Utah Code Annotated § 16-13-9 Requirement before commencing business -- Cash consideration for shares -- Minimum stated capital.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A development corporation incorporated after July 1, 1979, may not transact any business or incur any indebtedness, except as is incidental to its organization or to obtain subscriptions to or payment for its shares, until there has been paid in for the issuance of shares consideration in cash of at least $300,000.  A development corporation shall have a stated capital of not less than $300,000.

Utah Code Annotated § 16-13-10 Amount of net earnings set apart as earned surplus.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Each year a development corporation shall set apart as earned surplus not less than 10% of its net earnings for its preceding fiscal year until such surplus is equal in value to one-half of the amount paid in on the shares of the corporation then outstanding. Whenever the amount of surplus so established shall become impaired, it shall be restored to the required amount in the manner hereinbefore provided. Net earnings and surplus shall be determined by the board of directors, after providing for such reserves as said directors deem desirable, and the directors' determination made in good faith shall be conclusive on all persons.

Utah Code Annotated § 16-13-11 Designation of depository.
---------------------------------------------------------
A development corporation may not deposit any of its funds in any banking institution unless such institution has been designated as a depository by a vote of a majority of the directors present at an authorized meeting of the board of directors, exclusive of any director who is an officer or director of the depository so designated.  A development corporation may not receive money on deposit.

Utah Code Annotated § 16-13-12 Licensing, supervision, and examination by commissioner of financial institutions -- Fees.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A development corporation shall be licensed, supervised, and examined by the commissioner of financial institutions and shall make such report of its condition from time to time as the commissioner shall require.  A development corporation shall pay a fee determined by the commissioner pursuant to Section

Utah Code Annotated - Title 16 - Chapter 15 - Utah Business Trust Registration Act
**********************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-101 Title.
--------------------------------------
This act is known as the "Utah Business Trust Registration Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-102 Definition of business trust.
-------------------------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-102(1): "Beneficiary" means a person holding a certificate representing a beneficial interest in the trust estate and assets.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-102(2): 7-5-1 "Business trust" has the same meaning as in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-102(3): "Division" means the Division of Corporations and Commercial Code.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-102(4): "Person" means an individual, general partnership, limited liability partnership, limited partnership, limited liability company, limited association, domestic or foreign trust, estate, association, or corporation.


Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-103 Name.
-------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-103(1): 16-10a-401(5) The words "business trust" shall be the last words of the name of every business trust registered under this chapter.  The name of a business trust registered under this chapter shall be distinguishable, as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-103(2): A person who participates in the omission of the words "business trust" in the commercial use of the name of the business trust, or knowingly acquiesces in the omission is liable for any indebtedness, damage, or liability resulting from the omission.


Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-104 Registration required -- Certificate of registration.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-104(1): A business trust shall register with the division before doing business in the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-104(2): 16-17-203(1) The certificate of registration of a business trust shall set forth:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-104(2)(a): the name of the business trust;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-104(2)(b): the period of its duration;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-104(2)(c): the business purpose for which the business trust is organized;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-104(2)(d): 16-17-203(1) the information required by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-104(2)(e): the name, signature, and street address of all trustees of the business trust.


Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-105 Filing of certificate -- Fees.
--------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-105(1): A business trust is registered when two copies of the certificate of registration are filed with the division.  The documents to be filed shall be true copies made by photographic, xerographic, electronic, or other process that provides similar copy accuracy of a document that has been properly executed.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-105(2): The division shall endorse the original and one copy of a certificate of registration and:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-105(2)(a): file the original in the division office; and
Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-105(2)(b): return the copy to the trustee or the trustee's representative.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-105(3): 63J-1-504 The division may charge a fee in accordance with Section


Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-106 Powers.
---------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-106(1): A business trust registered under this chapter may in its trust name:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-106(1)(a): sue;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-106(1)(b): subject to the limitations in the declaration of trust, acquire title, lease, mortgage, convey or otherwise deal with real and personal property, or any interest in real and personal property.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-106(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-106(2)(a): A business trust may not maintain any action, suit, or proceeding in this state unless the business trust is registered under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-106(2)(b): A business trust may be sued whether or not the business trust is registered under this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-107 Expiration of filing -- Notice.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-107(1): (2) A filing under this chapter shall be effective for a period of three years from the date of filing plus the notice period provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-107(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-107(2)(a): If no new filing is made by or on behalf of the trust who made the original filing within three years of the date of filing, the division shall send a notice by regular mail, postage prepaid, to the address shown for the registered office in the filing indicating that it will expire 30 days after the division mailed the notice.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-107(2)(b): If no new filing is made within 30 days after the date of the division mailing the notice, the business trust's registration expires.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-107(3): If the registration of a business trust has expired or has been canceled for failure to maintain a registered agent, the business trust may not conduct business in this state until it has newly registered with the division under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-107(4): 63J-1-504 The division may charge a fee in accordance with Section


Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-108 When amendments are required.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-108(1): An amended certificate shall be filed with the division not later than 30 days after any change in:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-108(1)(a): any person acting as a trustee of the trust, or the address of any trustee;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-108(1)(b): the registered agent of the trust;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-108(1)(c): the registered office of the business trust; or
Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-108(1)(d): in any information required to be filed with the division under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-108(2): 16-15-105 The amended certificate shall be signed by each trustee of the business trust and filed in the same manner as a certificate of registration under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-108(3): 63J-1-504 The division may charge a fee in accordance with Section


Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-109 Registered agent.
-------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-109(1): A business trust shall continuously maintain an agent in this state for service of process on the business trust.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-109(2): The agent of the business trust shall be a person residing or authorized to do business in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-109(3): If a business trust fails to maintain a registered agent in this state, the division may cancel the business trust's registration.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-109(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-109(4)(a): The registered agent of a business trust may resign by filing an original and one copy of a signed written notice of resignation with the division.  The division shall mail a copy of the notice of resignation to the registered office of the business trust at the street address in the business trust's certificate of registration.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-109(4)(b): The appointment of the registered agent ends 30 days after the division receives notice of the resignation.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-109(5): 16-10a-1511; 16-10a-1521 Service may be effected on a business trust in the same manner prescribed for a corporation in Sections


Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-110 Trustee and beneficiary governed by declaration of trust -- Common law.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-110(1): A trustee or beneficiary of a business trust shall be governed by all the provisions of the declaration of trust of the business trust.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-15-110(2): This chapter neither affects nor alters in any way the rights, powers, and obligations, of a trustee or beneficiary of a business trust under common law.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 16 - Chapter 16 - Uniform Limited Cooperative Association Act
*****************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-101 Title.
--------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Uniform Limited Cooperative Association Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-102 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
In this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-102(1): 16-16-302 "Articles of organization" means the articles of organization of a limited cooperative association required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-102(2): "Board of directors" means the board of directors of a limited cooperative association.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-102(3): "Bylaws" means the bylaws of a limited cooperative association.  The term includes the bylaws as amended or restated.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-102(4): "Certificate of authority" means a certificate issued by the division for a foreign cooperative to transact business in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-102(5): 16-16-1008(3) "Contribution," except as used in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-102(6): "Cooperative" means a limited cooperative association or an entity organized under any cooperative law of any jurisdiction.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-102(7): 16-16-117(1)(a) "Designated office" means the office that a limited cooperative association or a foreign cooperative is required to designate and maintain under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-102(8): "Director" means a director of a limited cooperative association.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-102(9): 16-16-1007(5) "Distribution," except as used in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-102(10): "Division" means the Division of Corporations and Commercial Code.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-102(11): "Entity" means a person other than an individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-102(12): Part 10, Contributions, Allocations, and Distributions; Part 12, Dissolution; Part 7, Marketing Contracts "Financial rights" means the right to participate in allocations and distributions as provided in
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-102(13): "Foreign cooperative" means an entity organized in a jurisdiction other than this state under a law similar to this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-102(14): "Governance rights" means the right to participate in governance of a limited cooperative association.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-102(15): "Investor member" means a member that has made a contribution to a limited cooperative association and:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-102(15)(a): is not required by the organic rules to conduct patronage with the association in the member's capacity as an investor member in order to receive the member's interest; or
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-102(15)(b): is not permitted by the organic rules to conduct patronage with the association in the member's capacity as an investor member in order to receive the member's interest.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-102(16): "Limited cooperative association" means an association organized under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-102(17): "Member" means a person that is admitted as a patron member or investor member, or both, in a limited cooperative association.  The term does not include a person that has dissociated as a member.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-102(18): 16-16-601 "Member's interest" means the interest of a patron member or investor member under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-102(19): "Members meeting" means an annual members meeting or special meeting of members.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-102(20): "Organic law" means the statute providing for the creation of an entity or principally governing its internal affairs.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-102(21): "Organic rules" means the articles of organization and bylaws of a limited cooperative association.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-102(22): "Organizer" means an individual who signs the initial articles of organization.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-102(23): "Patron member" means a member that has made a contribution to a limited cooperative association and:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-102(23)(a): is required by the organic rules to conduct patronage with the association in the member's capacity as a patron member in order to receive the member's interest; or
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-102(23)(b): is permitted by the organic rules to conduct patronage with the association in the member's capacity as a patron member in order to receive the member's interest.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-102(24): "Patronage" means business transactions between a limited cooperative association and a person which entitle the person to receive financial rights based on the value or quantity of business done between the association and the person.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-102(25): "Person" means an individual, corporation, business trust, cooperative, estate, trust, partnership, limited partnership, limited liability company, limited cooperative association, joint venture, association, public corporation, government or governmental subdivision, agency, or instrumentality, or any other legal or commercial entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-102(26): "Principal office" means the principal executive office of a limited cooperative association or foreign cooperative, whether or not in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-102(27): "Record," used as a noun, means information that is inscribed on a tangible medium or that is stored in an electronic or other medium and is retrievable in perceivable form.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-102(28): 16-16-114 "Required information" means the information a limited cooperative association is required to maintain under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-102(29): "Sign" means, with present intent to authenticate or adopt a record:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-102(29)(a): to execute or adopt a tangible symbol; or
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-102(29)(b): to attach to or logically associate with the record an electronic symbol, sound, or process.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-102(30): "State" means a state of the United States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, the United States Virgin Islands, or any territory or insular possession subject to the jurisdiction of the United States.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-102(31): "Transfer" includes an assignment, conveyance, deed, bill of sale, lease, mortgage, security interest, encumbrance, gift, and transfer by operation of law.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-102(32): "Voting group" means any combination of one or more voting members in one or more districts or classes that under the organic rules or this chapter are entitled to vote and can be counted together collectively on a matter at a members meeting.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-102(33): "Voting member" means a member that, under the organic law or organic rules, has a right to vote on matters subject to vote by members under the organic law or organic rules.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-102(34): "Voting power" means the total current power of members to vote on a particular matter for which a vote may or is to be taken.


Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-103 Limited cooperative association subject to amendment or repeal of chapter.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A limited cooperative association governed by this chapter is subject to any amendment or repeal of this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-104 Nature of limited cooperative association.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-104(1): A limited cooperative association organized under this chapter is an autonomous, unincorporated association of persons united to meet their mutual interests through a jointly owned enterprise primarily controlled by those persons, which permits combining:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-104(1)(a): ownership, financing, and receipt of benefits by the members for whose interests the association is formed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-104(1)(b): separate investments in the association by members who may receive returns on their investments and a share of control.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-104(2): (1) The fact that a limited cooperative association does not have one or more of the characteristics described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-105 Purpose and duration of limited cooperative association.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-105(1): A limited cooperative association is an entity distinct from its members.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-105(2): 7-1-103 A limited cooperative association may be organized for any lawful purpose, whether or not for profit, except for the operation of a financial institution as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-105(3): Unless the articles of organization state a term for a limited cooperative association's existence, the association has perpetual duration.


Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-106 Powers.
---------------------------------------
A limited cooperative association may sue and be sued in its own name and do all things necessary or convenient to carry on its activities.  An association may maintain an action against a member for harm caused to the association by the member's violation of a duty to the association or of the organic law or organic rules.

Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-107 Governing law.
----------------------------------------------
The law of this state governs:Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-107(1): the internal affairs of a limited cooperative association; and
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-107(2): the liability of a member as member and a director as director for the debts, obligations, or other liabilities of a limited cooperative association.


Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-108 Supplemental principles of law.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Unless displaced by particular provisions of this chapter, the principles of law and equity supplement this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-109 Requirements of other laws.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-109(1): This chapter does not alter or amend any law that governs the licensing and regulation of an individual or entity in carrying on a specific business or profession even if that law permits the business or profession to be conducted by a limited cooperative association, a foreign cooperative, or its members.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-109(2): A limited cooperative association may not conduct an activity that, under law of this state other than this chapter, may be conducted only by an entity that meets specific requirements for the internal affairs of that entity unless the organic rules of the association conform to those requirements.


Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-110 Relation to restraint of trade and antitrust laws.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
To the extent a limited cooperative association or activities conducted by the association in this state meet the material requirements for other cooperatives entitled to an exemption from or immunity under any provision of the restraint of trade or antitrust laws of this state, the association and its activities are entitled to the exemption or immunity.  This section does not create any new exemption or immunity for an association or affect any exemption or immunity provided to a cooperative organized under any other law.

Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-111 Name.
-------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-111(1): Use of the term "cooperative" or its abbreviation under this chapter is not a violation of the provisions restricting the use of the term under any other law of this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-111(2): 48-2e-108; 48-2e-1205
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-111(2)(a): 48-2e-108; 48-2e-1205 Notwithstanding Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-111(2)(a)(i): the words "limited cooperative association" or "limited cooperative"; or
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-111(2)(a)(ii): the abbreviation "L.C.A." or "LCA".
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-111(2)(b): "Cooperative" may be abbreviated as "Co-op" or "Coop".
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-111(2)(c): "Association" may be abbreviated as "Assoc." or "Assn."
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-111(2)(d): "Limited" may be abbreviated as "Ltd."
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-111(2)(e): 
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-111(2)(e)(i): Use of the term "cooperative" or its abbreviation as permitted by this chapter is not a violation of the provisions restricting the use of the term under any other law of this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-111(2)(e)(ii): A limited cooperative association or a member may enforce the restrictions on the use of the term "cooperative" under this chapter and any other law of this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-111(2)(e)(iii): A limited cooperative association or a member may enforce the restrictions on the use of the term "cooperative" under any other law of this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-111(3): (4); 16-16-112 Except as otherwise provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-111(3)(a): the name of any entity organized or authorized to transact business in this state;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-111(3)(b): 16-16-112 a name reserved under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-111(3)(c): an alternative name approved for a foreign cooperative authorized to transact business in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-111(4): A limited cooperative association may apply to the division for authorization to use a name that is not available.  The division shall authorize use of the name if:
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-111(4)(a): the person with ownership rights to use the name consents in a record to the use and applies in a form satisfactory to the division to change the name used or reserved to a name that is distinguishable upon the records of the division from the name applied for; or
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-111(4)(b): the applicant delivers to the division a certified copy of the final judgment of a court establishing the applicant's right to use the name in this state.


Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-112 Reservation of name.
----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-112(1): 16-16-111; 16-16-111 A person may reserve the exclusive use of the name of a limited cooperative association, including a fictitious name for a foreign cooperative whose name is not available under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-112(2): A person that has reserved a name for a limited cooperative association may transfer the reservation to another person by delivering to the division a signed notice of the transfer which states the name, street address, and, if different, the mailing address of the transferee.  If the person is an organizer of the association and the name of the association is the same as the reserved name, the delivery of articles of organization for filing by the division is a transfer by the person to the association.


Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-113 Effect of organic rules.
--------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-113(1): The relations between a limited cooperative association and its members are consensual.  Unless required, limited, or prohibited by this chapter, the organic rules may provide for any matter concerning the relations among the members of the association and between the members and the association, the activities of the association, and the conduct of its activities.
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-113(2): (2)(a); (i); 16-16-105(3); 16-16-303(2); 16-16-504; 16-16-508(2); 16-16-815(1); 16-16-820; 16-16-1202(1); 16-16-405(6); 16-16-1501; (3) The matters referred to in Subsections

Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-114 Required information.
-----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-114(1): (2) Subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-114(1)(a): a list containing the name, last known street address and, if different, mailing address, and term of office of each director and officer;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-114(1)(b): the initial articles of organization and all amendments to and restatements of the articles, together with a signed copy of any power of attorney under which any article, amendment, or restatement has been signed;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-114(1)(c): the initial bylaws and all amendments to and restatements of the bylaws;
Utah Code Annotated § 16-16-114(1)(d): all filed articles of merger and statements of conversion;
